content.description: The Vulgarian starts at the base of Pox on Vulgaria but climbs the perfect vertical gear crack two feet to the right of the bolts on Vulgaria. At the midway ledge the route merges with Pox on Vulgaria but does not use the bolts instead use the excellent horizontals for gear. A fine gear route for the 5.8 leader.
content.protection: Small to mid size cams - a .2 Camalot is handy near the top. This route is a great 5.8 route. Excellent protection. The .2  placement near the top gives a 5.8 leader confidence to make the step to under the roof to the last horizontal - also great gear.
content.location: Two feet to the right of Vulgaria

content.description:
A.K.A.

A Pox in Vulgaria

- A fantastic route for the grade, just not very long.  Well protected, good rock, and some good overhanging moves that require pulling on jugs with minimal feet.  Provides a nice pump for the portly.  Some of the stances were a little reachy, but were very logically placed.  The Smith & Tusting guide specifies that there are 8 bolts, so I may have skipped one, but it still wasn't run out.  A great view rewards those reaching the top.  Vulgaria can easily be top-roped from an approach trail on the east side of the cliff.
content.protection: 7 camouflauged bolts to a two bolt anchor (with a rappel ring and a quicklink).
content.location: Third route from the east end of the cliff (first bolted route).  Climbs the left side of an arete.  Walk off to the east or rappel from the anchors.

content.description: Start on top of a boulder under the roof at a perfect BD #3 horizontal crack. Pull onto the face and head for the sweet looking stembox and then pull through the roofs. Watch out for some loose blocks
content.protection: singles. 2 bolt/chain anchor
content.location: Left of squanto by about 30ft. Start on top of a boulder under the overhanging rock

content.description: Climb up obvious small buttress passing one bolt about 15‘ up. Continue straight up under overhang to broken hand crack that splits the 5’ horizontal roof. Out the roof is about 12-, or go right through Nick’s Notch for a 5.8 finish. Carefully place cams as to not inhibit jams. Pull roof on steep jugs. No anchor, walk off to right.
content.protection: Standard Rack, one bolt. No Anchors
content.location: Far left of the cliff lake crag. Maybe 15’ before the gully that comes in from the top.

content.description:
Like Rusty Corner, this route has probably been toproped previously.  But I don't think it is an established line. I asked around, including a local guide and noone knew of it having been climbed. There were several death blocks that I removed, so even toprope was risky for belayer.

The route begins in the inside corner to the right of Vulgarians.  Stem up the corner past 8 bolts and out the huge roof.  Way cool!
content.protection: 8 bolts, top anchor is quick clips
content.location: Huge inside corner that faces the lake

content.description: Far left bolted line on the wall. Start by standing on a boulder to reach the first bolt.
content.protection: 6 bolts with bolted anchors.

content.description:
Rusty corner: an overlooked, red-headed step child among many stellar routes at Cliff Lake. I really doubt I'm the first to climb it, but it totally goes and should be documented on MP. I'm pretty sure it hasn't been "established" because there are no bolted anchors for it and you must build a gear anchor. That said, I think it's a great reason to put the route up because it makes for a good lead for beginner trad climbers learning to place gear and build a gear anchor with pro.

Rusty corner is a little dirty, hence the name, but I found no loose rocks or blocks on it, and there are ample places for lots of pro all along the route. You can circumnavigate the short roof section by going left or right, or you can go straight through it for a little added difficulty. I would say going directly through the roof is about 5.7-.

There is a bomber vertical crack up top to build an anchor. The vertical crack takes 3s, a 2, and I found a horizontal crack for a small nut or micros.
content.protection: standard rack, gear anchor.
content.location: The routes starts in the obvious "rusty" looking corner/dihedral just to the right of butterface.

content.description: The crack is overgrown but the rock is pretty stable. Could be a fun climb for a new trad leader. The route is straight forward with no real crux to speak of. Make sure to take some webbing to sling a tree as an anchor. We had a first time "crag dog" with us, Pixel.
content.protection: Standard rack. Placed a couple of tri-cams if you have them. If you have long webbing, you can build an anchor on a tree to try and keep the rope drag down. Also able to walk off to the right.
content.location: Going past Mosquito Mayhem about 20 meters you'll pass a gully that can easily be scrambled up (this would be the top rope approach or the walk off path). The route is another couple meters past.

content.description: Start in left facing corner just left of Squanto. Traverse left under roof then straight up using horizontal cracks for pro. Clip a bolt out right and pull some hard moves through a notch to the juggy face above. Climb easy face up to bolted anchor.
content.protection: Standard rack, one bolt. Two bolt anchor with chains at top.
content.location: Just left of Squanto. Right side of large "cave" on west side of Cliff lake wall.

climbs.name: No Woman, No Cry
climbs.fa: Brian Cabe, Matt Scullian, Dwight Curry

content.description: Several variations for start and middle, crux is pulling mini roof at top onto sloping face where anchors are located.
content.protection: 8 bolts, bolted anchor

climbs.name: Mosquito Mayhem
climbs.fa: Brian Cabe and Patricia Black 29 June 2002

content.description:
Climb up the low angle slab to the top of the crag.  Follows shallow corners and slots for pro and holds.

Nice, compact rock with plenty of holds and good protection.
content.protection:
Standard rack (set of stoppers, set of cams).

No fixed anchor at top.  Walk off to the right.
content.location: Located to the left of the main cluster of Cliff Lake Routes.  To the west of the main crag, go past a large break in the wall, past a short steep section, then a bit more to the left to the low angle slab.  Maybe around 50 meters or so past the other routes at the crag.

content.description:
Start into a vegetated v-shaped dihedral and quest left toward an obvious notch in the roof at the top of the cliff. Work past a shallow right facing corner to the final vertical section through the notch. Walk off from the top.

The route feels surprisingly vertical, but the pro is plentiful. Just watch out for one or two loose blocks while placing gear.
content.protection: A standard rack should be plenty. A few extra finger-size pieces gives you the opportunity to stitch this thing up.
content.location: This route is toward the left end of the wall past all the bolted lines. Find the notch just right of the most dramatic section of roof, then look down and right to the vegetated low-angle dihedral right above a missing block at the base of the climb.

content.description:
A real fun route that follows a crack to a large, funky roof.

Begin off the ground and fire the direct, steep start or work you way up and in from the left, either way, get up and gain composure on a small ledge.  Follow the more continuous, larger, vertical crack up until you meet the base of the roof. A little bit of shuffling and maybe some grunting leads to a bolt at the routes crux, crank on and enjoy the view.
content.protection: A single rack of nuts and cams up to two inches, slings and a few draws. Chain anchor.
content.location:
Lake Effect

shares the right side of

Cliff Lake

with

Gobslutch

content.description: First climb on the right side of the cliff.  Starts off in a roof crack to a face, then traverse left to another roof, clip a bolt pull the roof and climb to anchors.
content.protection: Small rack to #2 or 3 with 1 bolt and bolted anchors.

content.description:
A.K.A.

What Price for Glory?

-

Glory

is a nearly vertical face with lots of jugs and edges for feet.  An occasional sidepull or smear provides additional challenge.  Fairly consistent for the grade, but not very committing due to the abundance of protection.  The bolt line heads straight up a face just to the right of a system of cracks and weaknesses.  Then, it suddenly shifts to the left for one last bolt.  This bulge section seems to provide the crux of the climb.  This is a good route for beginners.
content.protection: 8 camouflaged bolts to a two bolt anchor (one rappel ring and a quicklink).
content.location: Fourth route from the east.  Just right of a broken, right-facing dihedral.  Walk off to the east or rappel from the two bolt anchor.

content.description: This is a great "school house" easy crack climb/laying dihedral off of the slab.  Still needs major cleaning, as there is a forest of green growing in and out of the crack.  Great area to practice placing gear and transitioning belays.  No real crux to speak of, the climbing is fairly consistent.
content.protection: Cams up to #3, wired nuts.  No bolts or fixed gear.  Climb off the top to the right, or down climb.
content.location: To the immediate right of the Mosquito Mayhem slab.  There is an obvious short dihedral to the right of the base of the climb.  Maybe 100 yds. to the left of Vulgaria.

content.description:
A great route on a good wall,

Chilly Dogs

starts off burly working its way past a few bolts, up and around a large roof. Stick with it and gain a quick rest. Delicate climbing past another small roof leads to a steep and solid head wall. Long pulls over great rock, finish on a nice ledge.
content.protection: Eight bolts to an anchor.
content.location:
Chilly Dogs

sits heavy on the left side of the crag. It is the second bolted route from the left and is easily recognized by its large, intimidating roof.

content.description: Follow the small ramp and shoot for the hand crack splitting the top of the wall. Watch for loose blocks.
content.protection: Standard rack, belay off the first alive tree 20ish feet from the big legde you top out on.
content.location: After you walk past all the routes to the right, look left of the gully type feature and you'll see a disgusting line that has your name all over it. Wander up the short ramp and aim for the hand crack splitting the top. It's quite loose.

content.description:
A pretty good route on a rather pretty face?

Butter Face

offers a lot of fun and a few upper pitch variations. This route is best done as a warm-up or warm-down, but if you brought the gear just do it.

Butter Face

is a nice steep pitch over easy terrain. A cool set of fractures over forgiving and solid rock lead the climber to a big rest at the 3/4's mark. From here choose the finish the best suits you. A more mellow, standard approach climbs to the right over easy terrain and great gear placements. Another option leans left over a blank spot with less gear and more go juice!

You can't deny it, you know you wan to try it.
content.protection:
A standard rack up to three inches should suffice, runners and a few draws. Build an anchor, sling a tree, do something up there, then rap off

No Woman No Cry
content.location:
Butter Face

lies in the center of

Cliff Lake

. It begins just left of

Glory

content.description: To the right of Glory is a black streaked crack that leads up to a roof at the top.  The crack is a bit dirty (lichen at the roof) but one does not need it for the most part as there are lots of other holds. Clearing the roof is bit problematic as there is loose but wedged block at the top.
content.protection: Cams up to a #3 Camalot (used to protect the finial move over the roof.
content.location: Look for the black streak between Glory and Vulgaria.
